newsitem.title: USA: U.S. to ease data codes export limits - newspaper.
newsitem.headline: U.S. to ease data codes export limits - newspaper.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton has decided to allow U.S. computer companies to export more powerful data scrambling software so long as they establish a system that will enable keys to the code to be obtained by law enforcement officials with a court warrant, the New York Times reported Tuesday.
The newspaper cited unidentified sources as saying Vice President Al Gore would announce the decision on October 2 or October 3.
The decision would come into effect January 1, it added.
Although several companies like IBM Corp had agreed to the system suggested by Clinton's administration, many others would likely reject it, the newspaper said.
Computer companies have frequently criticized the export restriction imposed on them, saying it put them at a disadvantage against products sold by their foreign competitors, it said.
The newspaper said the government had feared that a lighter restriction would allow terrorists and other criminal organizations to use the software.
